We collect our datasets from Purdue Universityâ€™s online courses on the edX platform (\urlwww.edx.org). We study three graduate-level online courses: Fiber Optic Communications (FOC), Quantum Detectors and Sensors (QDS), and Essentials of MOSFETs (MOSFETs).
Each course consists of a series of lecture videos, some of which have an end-of-video quiz that assesses student learning progress.
Moreover, each course provides a discussion forum page for students to discuss with each other.
The platform also records each studentâ€™s final grade, which is a pass or fail label based on the grading policy.
Summary statistics of the three courses are given in TableÂ I, emphasizing a broad range of activity levels for our evaluation.
The pass rate distributions for each student subgroup are also summarized in TableÂ II.

For both the knowledge tracing task (TablesÂ VII,Â IX, andÂ XI) and the outcome prediction task (TablesÂ VIII,Â X, andÂ XII), we see that our ML-PFL methodology obtains substantial improvements over the non-personalized models on each demographic subgroup. Specifically, for the FOC and QDS datasets, we obtain 15-35% improvement in AUC over the highest performing non-personalized model across subgroups.
The improvements obtained by the personalized models are noticeable but more limited in the MOSFETs dataset, possibly due to its overall smaller size (see TableÂ I).
For both downstream tasks, MLPFL consistently outperforms FedIRT except in 4 of the Â 50 subgroup cases across courses, confirming the benefits offered by our meta learning-based personalization approach. This improvement validates our hypothesis that weighting student subgroups based on their â€œdata qualityâ€ as in FedIRT may lose important information on subgroup heterogeneity, which is captured by our redefinition of the global model inÂ (6).
Moreover, FedIRT does not consider course-specific modeling, whereas our personalized architecture adapts the student models across different courses and demographics.

S4.T3.caption: TABLE III: The configurations of baseline settings. sc1 and sc2 represent the first and second scenario, and L, G and P denote local, global, and personalized model, respectively. For <<Aggregation>>, AV and AT represent average- and attention-based method when model aggregation. For scenario II, we have three hierarchies, representing demographic, course, and global level. We use B, M and T to show the bottom, middle, and top of the hierarchies in scenario II.
S4.T3.table:
Configuration Attribute
<<Scenario>> sc1, sc2
<<Architecture>> L, G, P
<<Aggregation>> AV, AT
<<Hierarchy>> (optional) B, M, T
references:
We compare the performance of MLPFL against baselines in several different configurations.
These configurations differ in terms of several attributes: (i) scenario (i.e., scenario I and II we introduced in SectionÂ 2.1 andÂ 2.2), (ii) architecture (i.e., local (L), global (G), and personalized (P) model), (iii) FL aggregation method (i.e., average-based aggregation (AV), attention-based aggregation (AT)), and (iv) hierarchy information (for the scenario with demographic personalization).
For conciseness, we will use a general structure [<<Scenario>>-<<Architecture>>-<<Aggregation>>-<<Hierarchy>>] to represent each baseline according to the attributes listed in TableÂ III.
<<Hierarchy>> appears for scenario II to indicate which level of the hierarchy â€“ bottom (B), middle (M), top (T) â€“ is used for the final adapted model.
For example, [sc1-G-AV] represents the global model with average-based aggregation in scenario I, and [sc2-P-AT-B] corresponds to the personalized model that adapts the attention-aggregated global model based on the data of the bottom level (demographic subgroups) in scenario II.

references:
We perform 5-fold cross-validation on each dataset and randomly select 20% of the students in the training set for validation.
For all neural network architecturesâ€“ LSTM in Knowledge Tracing and GRU in Outcome Predictionâ€“ the hidden state dimension is 48.
50 training epochs are used for non-FL approaches ([sc1-L], [sc1-G], [sc2-L], and [sc2-G]), and for FL methods, the global aggregations (Kğ¾K) and local iterations (Eğ¸E) are set to be 10 and 5, respectively.
For all models, the hyper-parameters are determined by a grid search over the search space given in TableÂ IV.
We test all combinations of parameters for each model and use the one achieving the highest accuracy in Section Â 4.3.

In TablesÂ V and VI, we compare our method to the baselines in terms of the predictive quality of knowledge tracing and outcome prediction achieved on each course in scenario I.
For scenario II, Table Â VII, Â IX, and Â XI compare the performance of knowledge tracing on each student group for our method and the baselines, while TableÂ VIII, Â X, and Â XII are the results for outcome prediction.
Finally, FigureÂ 3 compares the distribution of AUCs obtained by FedIRT and MLPFL across all courses and demographic subgroups.

In TablesÂ VII, IX, and XI, for knowledge tracing, we observe that the local model [sc2-L] provides on average 54% AUC on each subgroup according to different demographic groupings , and in TablesÂ VIII,Â X, and Â XII, we find on average 60% AUC for outcome prediction.
While providing moderate improvements over [sc1-L], these results confirm our hypothesis that small subgroups do not have enough data to train high accuracy models individually..
On the other hand, unlike in scenario I, we see that the centralized global model [sc2-G] does not necessarily outperform the global federated models ([sc2-G-AV-M]&[sc2-G-AT-M] and [sc2-G-AV-T]&[sc2-G-AT-T]).
This is particularly true for underrepresented subgroups.
For example, in TableÂ VIII, for the MOSFETs dataset, [sc2-G] obtains the highest performance for the male subgroup among the non-personalized models, while two of the global FL models noticeably outperform it on the female subgroup. As another example, in Table 10, for the QDS dataset, [sc2-G-AT-M] outperforms [sc2-G] noticeably for all subgroups except North America. By systematically incorporating such subgroup heterogeneity, the personalized models are able to obtain substantial improvements across datasets and subgroups, as we discuss further next.
